subject: Re: [junit] Re: Are you really using JUnit during your development?

There are always extremes.  Anything can be overdone, and therefore result =
in loss of benefit.  The trick is optimizing your outcome.

I don't think t=
hat most people who are truly practicing TDD (following the intent, if not =
the letter) could be "obsessed over tests to the exclusion of customer sati=
sfaction".

I look at TDD as being driven largely by customer need.  If I d=
on't understand the customer need (and therefore how to satisfy them), then=
 I don't know what to test for.  If I don't know what to test for, I don't =
know what to write.  Therefore, if my tests are based on meeting customer n=
eed (which drives customer satisfaction), then I inherently should improve =
customer satisfaction with every test I write, because it will result in co=
de that meets their needs.

Being focused on the customer, though, I will a=
lso realize that writing umpteen-million tests for one piece of functionali=
ty, to the detriment of not creating other necessary functionality, would n=
ot enhance customer satisfaction.  :)

It's a balancing act, but well worth=
 the effort.


my two cents,
Dianne

ha! Aha! Aha!

ere already experienced programmers way
before TDD came about...

TDD is no=
t better than a "design driven by careful thought", precisely
> because TDD=
 is /a method for thinking carefully about a design/!

TDD can also lead to=
 subpar design, precisely because of the obsession over
the tests at the ex=
clusion of all other factors (such as, I don't know,
customer satisfaction =
:-)).
